subject: Cooking
title: Searing Meat Doesn't Seal in Juices
description: A 60-second lesson on Searing Meat Doesn't Seal in Juices.

hook.text: Every cooking show says it: sear meat to 'seal in the juices.' It's the biggest myth in the kitchen.

buildup.text: German chemist Justus von Liebig proposed this theory in 1850. Cooks have repeated it ever since.

discovery.text: Experiments show seared meat actually loses more moisture than meat cooked gently from the start.

twist.text: Searing is still valuable â€” but for flavor, not moisture. The Maillard reaction creates hundreds of tasty compounds.

climax.text: A crust doesn't seal anything. It's porous. Juices escape freely through cracks in the seared surface.

punchline.text: Sear for flavor, not for sealing. The juice myth is 170 years overdue for.

quiz.question: Why should you sear meat according to food science?
